  ', 'Your codespace will open once ready.', 'There was a problem preparing your codespace, please try again.', ' has served the Python community well for many years, but it is no
longer the best option for providing time zones. ', ' has a non-standard
interface that is ', '; this
interface was necessary when ', ' was created, because ', ' had no
way to represent ambiguous datetimes, but this was solved in Python 3.6,
which added a ', ' attribute to datetimes in ', '. With the addition of the
', ' module in Python 3.9 (', '), there has never been a better
time to migrate away from ', '.', 'However, since ', ' time zones are used very differently from a standard
', ', and many libraries have built ', ' zones into their standard
time zone interface (and thus may have users relying on the existence of the
', ' and ', ' methods); this library provides shim classes
that are compatible with both PEP 495 and ', "'s interface, to make it
easier for libraries to deprecate ", '.', 'This library is intended for ', ', and should allow you to
drop your dependency on ', ' while also giving your users notice that
eventually you will remove support for the ', '-specific interface.', 'Within your own code, use ', ' shims as if they
were ', ' or ', ' zones — do not use ', ' or
', ':', 'Datetime addition will work ', ',
even across a daylight saving time transition:', 'However, if you have exposed a time zone to end users who are using ', '
and/or ', ' or any other ', "-specific features (or if you've
failed to convert some of your own code all the way), those users will see
a warning (rather than an exception) when they use those features:", 'For IANA time zones, calling ', ' on the shim zones (and indeed on ', '
and ', ' zones as well) returns the IANA key, so end users who would
like to actively migrate to a ', ' (or ', ') can do
so:', '
